A journalist writes a report with biased opinions presented as facts, and when confronted, avoids accountability by stating that the editor approved the piece.

A social media influencer posts a detailed review of a product with misleading claims, and when followers question the accuracy, the influencer denies responsibility, saying the brand provided the information.
The editor-in-chief of a Riyadh daily newspaper fails to review an article containing false information about a government policy, which leads to public confusion and official complaints.
During the editor-in-chief’s absence, the acting editor publishes an opinion piece with unverified claims about a local business, causing reputational damage and prompting legal threats.
The editor-in-chief ignores multiple warnings from the editorial team about a published article containing hate speech, resulting in public backlash and calls for accountability.
While the editor-in-chief is on leave, the deputy editor allows the publication of misleading images in a front-page story without fact-checking, leading to widespread misinformation.
A blogger publishes an article about health remedies without verifying the sources, spreading misinformation that leads readers to try unsafe treatments.
An author releases a book containing unverified historical claims and offensive stereotypes, ignoring feedback and refusing to issue corrections.
A social media influencer posts a detailed guide on financial investments without disclaimers or fact-checking, resulting in followers making poor financial decisions.
A journalist writes an opinion piece filled with false accusations about a public figure, neglecting to fact-check or seek comments from the accused party.

A Riyadh-based newspaper publishes an article quoting a local business owner as supporting a controversial policy, but the owner never made such a statement. When the owner requests a correction, the newspaper refuses to publish it.

A newspaper in Jeddah reports that a university professor made derogatory remarks about a religious group. The professor denies the claim and asks for a free correction, but the newspaper ignores the request and leaves the false statement uncorrected.

An article in a Dammam daily incorrectly attributes a political opinion to a government official. After the official contacts the newspaper to request a correction, the paper delays the response and eventually publishes a paid correction instead of a free one.

A newspaper in Mecca prints a story falsely claiming that a local charity misused funds. The charity demands a free correction to clear its name, but the newspaper refuses, causing public distrust to persist.

A local newspaper in Jeddah publishes an article claiming a new government policy will increase taxes on basic goods, which is false. When readers request a correction, the newspaper ignores the requests and does not publish any clarification.

A Riyadh-based daily prints a story about a public figure involved in a scandal without verifying facts. After the individual contacts the paper to demand a correction, the newspaper refuses to publish any correction or apology, leaving the misinformation unaddressed.

A regional newspaper in Dammam reports incorrect statistics about unemployment rates, causing public concern. Despite multiple complaints from readers and officials, the newspaper fails to issue a free correction or clarification.

An online news outlet in Mecca publishes a false report about a health crisis in the city. When authorities request a correction to prevent panic, the outlet declines to publish any correction or update, maintaining the inaccurate story on their site.

A Riyadh-based newspaper publishes an article with incorrect information about a local business. After the business requests a correction, the newspaper delays publishing it until the third issue, ignoring the requirement to include it in the very next edition.

A Dammam daily prints a story with factual errors about a public official. The official submits a formal correction request, but the newspaper fails to include the correction in the immediate next issue, instead publishing it a week later.
A newspaper in Jeddah reports false details about a community event. When organizers request a correction, the paper does not publish it in the following issue, causing confusion among readers.

After a newspaper in Al Khobar misquotes a local expert, the expert demands a correction. The newspaper neglects to print the correction in the first issue after the request, only addressing it after multiple complaints.

A local newspaper in Jeddah publishes an article with incorrect information about a public figure but later prints the correction in a small, obscure section at the back of the paper, where few readers notice it.

A Riyadh daily releases a front-page story containing false data about a government policy, but the correction appears only in a brief note buried within the classifieds section, failing to reach the original article’s audience.

After publishing a misleading report on a business scandal, a newspaper in Dammam places the correction in a minor column on the last page instead of near the original article, leaving many readers unaware of the update.

A newspaper in Mecca prints an erroneous statement about a local event on page three but publishes the correction in a small font on page ten, far from the original story and not in a prominent position.
A local newspaper in Jeddah publishes an article with incorrect information about a public figure but refuses to print the correction in the next issue without charging a fee.
A Riyadh-based daily prints a misleading report about a government policy and, when requested to issue a correction, demands payment from the affected party before publishing it.
After publishing false details about a business owner in Dammam, a newspaper agrees to print a correction only if the owner pays for the advertisement space.
A newspaper in Al Khobar prints an erroneous story about a community event and delays the free correction for weeks, citing internal policy, causing public confusion.

A local business owner in Jeddah is falsely accused in a widely shared online article of engaging in illegal activities. Despite the damage to his reputation, the publisher refuses to issue a correction or offer any compensation.

A teacher in Riyadh is wrongly reported by a popular news outlet as having been involved in a scandal. When she tries to seek redress for the harm caused to her career, the media company denies her any compensation or apology.

A small restaurant owner in Dammam is the subject of a viral social media post containing false claims about food safety violations. The post leads to a significant drop in customers, but the person who posted it refuses to take responsibility or compensate for the losses.

An artist in Al Khobar is misquoted in a national newspaper, leading to public backlash and canceled exhibitions. When the artist requests a formal correction and compensation for the damage, the newspaper declines to respond.

A publishing company in Jeddah prints a travel guidebook that includes detailed maps showing restricted military zones, which is prohibited. The Ministry orders the immediate withdrawal of all copies from bookstores.

A local magazine in Riyadh publishes an article containing sensitive political commentary that violates Article 9. The Ministry issues a directive to recall all distributed issues and halt further printing.

A university in Dammam distributes brochures for an event that contain unauthorized religious content deemed prohibited. The Ministry intervenes and mandates the removal of all printed materials from circulation.

A printing press in Mecca produces flyers advertising a concert, but the flyers include images and text that violate cultural norms outlined in Article 9. The Ministry demands the destruction of all printed flyers and stops the event promotion.

A publishing company in Jeddah prints a travel guidebook that includes maps showing restricted military zones. The Ministry reviews the book and orders all copies to be withdrawn from stores without compensation.

A local magazine in Riyadh publishes an article containing unauthorized political content deemed prohibited by Article 9. The Ministry mandates the immediate removal of all printed issues and confiscates remaining stock.
A university presses a textbook that contains excerpts from banned literature. After inspection, the Ministry instructs the publisher to withdraw all printed copies without any reimbursement.

A printing house produces flyers for a cultural event, but the materials include images and text violating Article 9. The Ministry intervenes and orders the destruction of all printed flyers without compensation.

A preliminary committee is formed in Jeddah to review cases of public decency violations, but the chairperson is a government official with no legal background, leading to questions about the legitimacy of their decisions.

In Riyadh, a committee tasked with evaluating traffic law violations is established, but the head is a senior police officer without any judicial training, causing delays and appeals from those penalized.
At a municipal office in Dammam, a committee reviews environmental regulation breaches, yet the chair lacks judicial experience, resulting in inconsistent penalty enforcement and public criticism.

A committee in Mecca is set up to handle commercial licensing violations, but the chairperson is a business administrator with no legal qualifications, leading to challenges against the committee’s authority.
A company in Jeddah forms a preliminary committee to review a contract dispute but fails to include a legal advisor, leading to incomplete assessments of the legal implications.

At a government department in Riyadh, a preliminary committee is established to evaluate new regulations, but no legal advisor is appointed, resulting in recommendations that overlook key legal requirements.
A university in Dammam creates a preliminary committee to investigate a faculty grievance, but the committee lacks a legal advisor, causing delays when legal issues arise during the process.
A municipal council in Al Khobar forms a preliminary committee to assess land use applications, but omits a legal advisor, which leads to challenges when legal compliance questions are raised later.
A government department in Jeddah forms a committee to organize a public awareness campaign but fails to include a media specialist, resulting in poor communication and low public engagement.

At a municipal office in Dammam, a preliminary committee is established to plan a city event, but no media expert is invited, leading to ineffective press coverage and missed opportunities for publicity.
A health authority in Riyadh creates a task force to address a new health initiative, but the committee lacks a media specialist, causing delays in disseminating accurate information to the public.
During preparations for a cultural festival in Al Khobar, the organizing committee is formed without a media professional, resulting in inconsistent messaging and confusion among attendees.

At a municipal office in Jeddah, a preliminary committee reviews a complaint submitted by a local activist group that was not filed by an individual directly affected nor referred by the Minister, leading to confusion about the committee’s authority to proceed.

During a meeting in Riyadh, a preliminary committee begins investigating a complaint about a public project based on a letter from a third-party organization without direct interest or ministerial referral, causing members to question the validity of the complaint.

In a government building in Dammam, a preliminary committee receives a complaint from a private company about a competitor’s practices, but the complaint was neither filed by a directly impacted party nor referred by the Minister, resulting in the committee halting the review.

At a public hearing in Mecca, a preliminary committee starts examining a complaint submitted by a media outlet without direct capacity or ministerial referral, prompting the chairperson to remind members that such complaints are outside their jurisdiction.
A preliminary committee in Jeddah reviews a case of alleged noise disturbance and issues a fine without inviting the accused resident to present their side or send a representative.
In Riyadh, a traffic violation committee imposes a penalty on a driver based solely on police reports, without notifying the driver or allowing them to attend a hearing.

At a municipal office in Dammam, a committee decides to revoke a business license due to complaints but does not summon the business owner or their lawyer to provide an explanation before making the decision.
A labor dispute committee in Al Khobar rules against a worker’s claim without calling the worker or their representative to give testimony or respond to the allegations.
During a labor dispute case in Jeddah, the preliminary committee issues a ruling against the employee without inviting the employer to present their side or provide any statement.
In a commercial licensing review in Riyadh, the committee decides to revoke a business license without summoning the owner for a hearing or allowing them to respond to the allegations.

In a disciplinary case at a university in Mecca, the committee suspends a student without inviting the student to attend a meeting or provide any explanation before the decision.
At a Riyadh public market, a visitor sets up a small stand selling unlicensed souvenirs without obtaining the required permits, leading to intervention by local authorities.
In a Dammam shopping center, a tourist distributes flyers promoting an unapproved event, ignoring warnings from security and continuing despite requests to stop.
At a public park in Jeddah, a visitor plays loud music from a portable speaker, disturbing families and violating noise regulations, resulting in a fine from municipal officers.
During a cultural festival in Al Khobar, a foreign vendor sells food items without adhering to health and safety standards mandated by the law, prompting officials to shut down the stall.
Ahmed, a visitor in Jeddah, was fined for smoking in a non-smoking area at a public park. Despite the fine, a week later he was caught smoking again in the same area, leading to a doubled fine.
Sarah, a tourist in Riyadh, was initially fined for littering in a public square. She ignored the warning and repeated the offense the next day, causing authorities to impose a doubled fine.
During a festival in Dammam, John was fined for playing loud music in a public place. He repeated the behavior the following day, resulting in the fine being doubled.
At a shopping mall in Mecca, Maria was fined for wearing indecent clothing. She returned the next day wearing similar attire, which led to the fine being doubled by security officials.
Ahmed, a journalist previously suspended for violating press regulations, attempts to submit an article to a Riyadh newspaper, but the editor refuses to publish it due to the suspension order.

Fatima, whose suspension from writing in all printed media is publicly known, tries to contribute an opinion piece to a local magazine in Jeddah, but the publisher rejects her submission citing the official ban.

During a press conference in Dammam, Khalid, who is under suspension from writing in newspapers, hands out printed flyers containing his articles, leading authorities to confiscate the materials and remind him of the suspension.

Sara, suspended from contributing to any printed publications, posts copies of her banned articles at a university bulletin board in Riyadh, prompting campus security to remove the materials and report the violation.
A well-known journalist, previously suspended from media branding, appears on a live satellite news channel broadcast from abroad, discussing local political issues despite the suspension.

Ahmed, a journalist previously suspended for violating media regulations, attempts to publish an article in a local newspaper under a pen name, but the editorial team refuses to print it due to his suspension.

Sara, banned from media branding, attempts to promote her satellite TV program through social media ads targeting viewers in Saudi Arabia, but the ads are removed by platform moderators following official complaints.

The Minister delays issuing the official guidelines for the appellate committee, causing confusion among members about how to handle appeals and leading to inconsistent decisions.

Due to the absence of clear work procedures from the Minister, the preliminary committee in Riyadh holds meetings without a standardized agenda or documentation process, resulting in disputes over case handling.

The Minister fails to publish the rules regulating the timeline for submitting appeals, leaving applicants uncertain about deadlines and causing multiple appeals to be rejected for procedural reasons.

Without ministerial rules, the appellate committee members in Jeddah independently create their own procedures, leading to conflicting practices and complaints from stakeholders about fairness and transparency.

The Minister receives a complaint about a commercial dispute but assigns the preliminary committee from a different jurisdiction that has no authority over the case, causing delays in the legal process.
During a regulatory review, the Minister incorrectly delegates an appellate committee to hear an appeal that falls outside its territorial jurisdiction, leading to the appeal being invalidated.

The Minister issues a directive assigning a preliminary committee to investigate a labor dispute, but the committee is from a region not covered by the law, resulting in confusion and a formal complaint.
In a complex tax case, the Minister fails to clarify which appellate committee has jurisdiction, causing both committees to claim authority and delaying the resolution for several months.
In Riyadh, a government department announces the formation of a new appellate committee and publishes the names of its chairman and members on their official website without obtaining a royal order.
A municipal office in Jeddah holds a press conference to introduce the members of a preliminary committee and discusses their salaries publicly, despite lacking the required royal approval.
At a government building in Dammam, officials distribute internal memos appointing committee members and setting their remunerations, bypassing the formal royal decree process.
An agency in Mecca issues a public statement naming the chairman of a newly formed appellate committee and detailing their compensation package, without any royal order sanctioning the appointments.
In Riyadh, a member of the preliminary committee has served continuously for five years without re-election, despite the regulation limiting terms to three renewable years.
At an appellate committee meeting in Jeddah, a member who has already completed four consecutive terms is still participating in decision-making, exceeding the allowed term limit.
During a public announcement, it was revealed that a preliminary committee member in Dammam has been holding their position for six years, surpassing the maximum term duration.
In a committee session in Mecca, a member who has served three full terms and an additional year without formal renewal continues to act in their official capacity, violating the term limit rule.

The Ministry of Culture licenses a local publishing house to print a series of educational books. After distribution, the Ministry orders a withdrawal due to content concerns but fails to reimburse the publisher for the cost of the recalled copies.

A Ministry responsible for media oversight approves a magazine issue for print. Upon discovering unauthorized content, the Ministry demands the withdrawal of all copies but neglects to compensate the printing company for the expenses incurred.

The Ministry of Information licenses a newspaper to print a special edition. After publication, the Ministry requires the withdrawal of the edition due to inaccuracies but does not cover the financial losses faced by the newspaper for the unsold copies.

A Ministry overseeing publications authorizes a batch of brochures for distribution. When a legal issue arises, the Ministry orders the withdrawal of the brochures but fails to pay the printing firm for the withdrawn stock.

The Ministry of Culture issues a license for a new magazine, but after the first issue is published, it contains inaccurate historical information that causes public outrage. Despite the complaints, the Ministry delays withdrawing the magazine from circulation.

A publishing house receives approval from the Ministry of Information to print a book, but after discovering that the book includes unauthorized personal data, the Ministry fails to recall the printed copies promptly, allowing distribution to continue.

The Ministry licenses a newspaper that publishes an article with sensitive political content, sparking controversy. Even after official requests to retract the issue, the Ministry does not act to withdraw the printed copies from newsstands.

A Ministry grants permission for a brochure promoting a public event, but after errors are found in the safety instructions, the Ministry neglects to withdraw the brochures, leaving incorrect information accessible to the public.

The Ministry of Culture licenses a local publisher's new book, but after a few weeks, they decide to withdraw all copies from circulation due to content concerns. The publisher receives no compensation for the unsold and returned copies, causing financial loss.

A printing company receives approval from the Ministry of Information to distribute a magazine issue. Shortly after release, the Ministry orders a recall of all printed copies without prior notice or reimbursement, leaving the company with unsold inventory and no payment.

The Ministry licenses a newspaper's special edition, but after publication, they mandate a withdrawal due to a disputed article. The newspaper is forced to destroy thousands of copies and is not compensated for the printing costs.

A small publishing house prints a batch of educational materials approved by the Ministry of Education. When the Ministry later withdraws the materials citing policy changes, the publisher is left with unsold stock and no financial restitution.

The Ministry of Culture approves a print run of a new book but later decides to withdraw 1,000 copies due to content concerns. When compensating the publisher, they only cover 60% of the printing costs, leaving the publisher with a significant loss.

A publishing house releases a magazine issue licensed by the Ministry of Information. After a complaint, the Ministry orders the withdrawal of 5,000 copies but reimburses the publisher for only half the production expenses, causing financial strain.

The Ministry of Media licenses a batch of newspapers for distribution. Following a review, they mandate the recall of 2,000 copies but compensate the printing company for just 70% of the total cost, leading to disputes over the shortfall.

A printing company produces educational materials authorized by the Ministry of Education. After the Ministry withdraws a portion of the stock due to errors, they pay the printer less than the full cost of the withdrawn copies, prompting the company to file a formal complaint.

A university professor in Jeddah approves a research paper for publication without consulting the required legal guidelines or involving a qualified reviewer familiar with the Ministry's instructions.

An academic journal editor in Riyadh assigns the review and approval of a submitted thesis to a junior staff member who lacks the necessary expertise and has not been trained on the Ministry's publication regulations.
A publishing house in Dammam releases a book on Saudi history without having the manuscript reviewed by a certified specialist acquainted with the Ministry's laws and publication standards.

A conference organizer in Mecca approves the distribution of intellectual materials without ensuring that the content was vetted by qualified experts familiar with the Ministry's legal and procedural requirements.

Dr. Ahmed, a researcher at a Saudi university, submits a study on renewable energy without consulting the Ministry’s designated experts, even though the Ministry had offered part-time specialists to assist with the project.
